But considering there are thousands of companies that we would ideally be updating monthly, as well as future goals of also providing quick and digestible summaries and insights for newly released earnings and conference calls, breaking news, FED speeches, etc, this quickly becomes very costly.

For this reason, please consider **subscribing to our Patreon** or donating to enable QuickTick AI to provide as much value and up-to-date insight as possible to **allow you to make the most informed investment decisions with a level of efficiency not possible even a few years ago.** 100% of the funds will go straight to purchasing more API credits to continue expanding our high quality, up-to-date analysis for more and more companies, and further then into our future value-generating plans. Thanks! - QuickTick AI

# Cable One, Inc. (CABO) Sell-Side Analysis Report
**Date of Report:** October 11, 2024  
**Current Stock Price:** $335.22 (Yahoo Finance, as of market close Oct 11, 2024)  
**Market Capitalization:** $1.89B (Yahoo Finance, as of Oct 11, 2024)  
**52-Week Range:** $244.85 - $627.00  

## Company Overview (198 words)
Cable One, Inc. (CABO) is a leading U.S. broadband communications provider operating in smaller secondary and tertiary markets across 24 states, serving approximately 1 million customer relationships as of Q2 2024. The company delivers high-speed internet (primary revenue driver at ~73% of total), video programming, phone services, and WiFi hotspots under brands like Sparklight, Clearwave, and others. Unlike giants like Comcast or Charter, Cable One focuses on underserved non-urban areas (e.g., Idaho, Oklahoma, Midwest), where it often holds monopoly-like positions with limited competition. Founded as an offshoot of Washington Post Co. in 2015 (spun from Post-Newsweek), it emphasizes residential broadband with average revenue per user (ARPU) exceeding $140/month—among the highest in the sector. In Q2 2024 earnings (Aug 1, 2024), revenue was $405.5M (down 7.2% YoY), with internet customers flat at 972K but video subs declining 7.5% to 284K. EBITDA fell 11% to $173.3M (42.7% margin). The company invests in network upgrades (DOCSIS 3.1/4.0 and fiber) to combat cord-cutting and overbuilders, while pursuing divestitures for focus. Debt stands at ~$3.8B (net leverage 3.9x EBITDA), supporting share buybacks amid a challenging multi-dwelling unit (MDU) exposure.

## Recent Developments
- **Aug 1, 2024**: Q2 2024 earnings release – Revenue $405.5M (-7.2% YoY), net income $45.6M (-29% YoY), adjusted EBITDA $173.3M (-11% YoY), free cash flow $78.3M. Internet ARPU up 1.9% to $140.58; reaffirmed FY24 guidance (revenue $1.52-1.55B, EBITDA $640-665M).
- **Sep 9, 2024**: Announced divestiture of Midwest operations (IL, MN, TX; ~14K customers) to Megalight Networks for $85M cash (expected close Q4 2024), citing strategic refocus on core markets.
- **Oct 2024 discussions**: Investor forums (Seeking Alpha, Reddit r/stocks) highlight debt concerns amid rising interest rates; stock down ~45% YTD on sub losses and competition fears.
- **Earnings call (Aug 1)**: CEO Julia Laulis noted 98% DOCSIS 3.1 footprint, fiber-to-home (FTTH) passings up 20% YoY to 200K+ households.

## Growth Strategy
- Accelerate fiber deployments: Targeting 30-50K new FTTH passings quarterly; 2.5Gbps+ speeds in 85% footprint by 2025.
- Pricing discipline: 2-3% annual increases on internet tiers; bundling to stem video churn.
- Capital allocation: $200M+ annual capex (fiber/DOCSIS 4.0); $100M+ share repurchases YTD 2024; selective M&A/divestitures.
- Enterprise expansion: Growing business services (9% of revenue) via SMB fiber.

## Headwinds and Tailwinds
| Category | Headwinds | Tailwinds |
|----------|-----------|-----------|
| **Company-Specific** | High MDU exposure (35% customers) with lease expirations; video sub losses (-7.5% YoY Q2); $3.8B debt (rates up); sub stagnation amid fixed wireless access (FWA) competition. | Sticky broadband (1.1% churn); high ARPU ($140+); 42%+ EBITDA margins; buyback program (2.3M shares Q2). |
| **Sector-Wide** | Fiber overbuilders (AT&T/Verizon); T-Mobile/Verizon 5G FWA eroding low-end market; FCC BEAD funding favoring rivals; cord-cutting (video down industry-wide). | Rural broadband demand; limited HFC competition in Tier 2/3 markets; AI/data center backhaul needs boosting enterprise. |

## Products/Services
- **Existing**: High-speed internet (up to 2Gbps HFC, 5Gbps FTTH); video (1M+ channels); voice; advertising; business services (Ethernet, hosted IT).
- **New/Planned**: DOCSIS 4.0 rollout (2025 for multi-gig); FTTH expansion (500K passings by 2026); enterprise SD-WAN; Sparklight TV streaming app (beta 2024); AI-driven network optimization pilots.

## Market Share
- **Current Approximations**: ~1.5-2% U.S. residential broadband (1M customers vs. 130M+ total); 40-60% in core franchise areas (e.g., 50%+ in OK/ID per FCC data); #5-7 U.S. cableco by subs (behind Comcast, Charter, Altice).
- **Forecast**: Stable-to-slight decline (0-2% YoY sub growth through 2026 per BofA estimates); fiber gains offset by FWA/video erosion; market share dip to 1-1.5% nationally as competitors expand.

## Competitor Comparison
| Metric (Q2 2024 or Latest) | CABO | Charter (CHTR) | Comcast (CMCSA) | Altice (ATUS) |
|----------------------------|------|----------------|-----------------|---------------|
| **Internet Subs (M)** | 0.97 | 30.7 | 32.6 | 4.3 |
| **Rev Growth YoY** | -7.2% | -1.3% | +2.8% | -2.9% |
| **EBITDA Margin** | 42.7% | 41% | 39% | 38% |
| **ARPU (Internet)** | $140.58 | $63 | $70 | $85 |
| **FTTH %** | ~5% (growing) | <1% | 2% | 10% |
| **EV/EBITDA Multiple** | 6.2x | 8.5x | 7.8x | 5.5x |

*CABO premium ARPU but lags scale/efficiency; outperforms on margins.*

## Partnerships, M&A
- **Partnerships**: Adtraction (2024 digital ad platform); EchoStar/Dish for wireless trials; Cisco/Juniper for DOCSIS 4.0.
- **M&A/Divestitures**: Acquired Tegro (2023, $20M enterprise); divested Utah/Nevada to Liberty (2022, $1.1B); recent Midwest sale to Megalight (Sep 2024, $85M); no major buys since 2021.

## Current and Potential Major Clients
- **Current**: Residential (90% revenue: e.g., Sparklight households); SMBs (e.g., schools, hospitals in 24 states); enterprise (9%: data centers, carriers).
- **Potential**: BEAD-funded rural expansions; hyperscalers (AWS/Google backhaul via new fiber); MDU operators post-lease renewals.

## Other Qualitative Measures
- **ESG**: Strong network reliability (99.99% uptime); rural digital divide focus; B+ Sustainalytics rating.
- **Management**: CEO Julia Laulis (since 2018) praised for capital returns; activist pressure (Elliott 2023 stake) drove buybacks.
- **Sentiment**: Mixed – Barron's/WSJ articles (Sep-Oct 2024) note "undervalued asset" but "debt trap"; short interest ~5%.

## Financial Snapshot (Q2 2024 Earnings, Aug 1, 2024)
| Metric | Q2 2024 | YoY Change | FY24 Guidance |
|--------|---------|------------|---------------|
| **Revenue** | $405.5M | -7.2% | $1.52-1.55B |
| **Adj. EBITDA** | $173.3M | -11.1% | $640-665M |
| **Net Income** | $45.6M | -29.3% | N/A |
| **FCF** | $78.3M | +15% | $250-275M |
| **Capex** | $85.8M | -15% | $340-360M |

## Valuation and Recommendation
- **Buy Rating**: 4/10 (**Sell**). High debt (3.9x leverage), sub stagnation, and FWA/fiber threats outweigh premium margins/ARPU. Limited growth upside vs. peers; suitable for yield but not strong growth portfolios.
- **Estimated Fair Value**: $380/share (12-month target). Based on 8x 2025E EV/EBITDA ($700M; consensus), implying 13% upside. DCF (8% WACC, 2% growth) supports $350-410 range for moderate-risk growth investors. Risks: Debt refinancing (2026 maturity), recessionary churn.
